description: From Middle English male, borrowed from Old French malle, masle (Modern French mâle), from Latin masculus (“masculine, a male”), diminutive of mās (“male, masculine”). Doublet of macho. Displaced native Old English wǣpned (“male”, literally “penised”), derived from the noun wǣpn (“weapon”), which had the secondary sense “penis.”

adjectives.description: male (not generally comparable, comparative maler or more male, superlative malest or most male)

entries.meaning: Belonging to the sex which typically produces sperm, or to the gender which is typically associated with it. [from 14th c.]
examples: the leading male and female singers
a male bird feeding a seed to a female
in bee colonies, all drones are male

entries.meaning: Characteristic of this sex/gender. (Compare masculine, manly.)
examples: stereotypically male interests, an insect with typically male coloration

entries.meaning: Tending to lead to or regulate the development of sexual characteristics typical of this sex.
examples: the male chromosome;   like testes, ovaries also produce testosterone and some other male hormones

entries.meaning: (grammar, less common than 'masculine') Masculine; of the masculine grammatical gender.
examples: If you are describing a female noun, you must make the adjective feminine by adding an 'e'. If you describe a male noun, you add an 'er'. For neutral nouns you add an 'es'.

entries.meaning: (of bacteria) Having the F factor; able to impart DNA into another bacterium which does not have the F factor (a female).
(figuratively) Of instruments, tools, or connectors: designed to fit into or penetrate a female counterpart, as in a connector, pipe fitting or laboratory glassware. [from 16th c.]
examples: Male adapter connects female pipe threads to polyethylene cold-water pipe; [...] female flare coupling connects male pipe threads to flared copper or plastic;

definitionGroups.group: One of the male (masculine) sex or gender.

entries.meaning: A human member of the masculine sex or gender.
An animal of the sex that has testes.
A plant of the masculine sex.
A bacterium which has the F factor.
A male connector, pipe fitting, etc.
